quizzes.question: Which tag is used to create shape animations?
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Shape Animations [/h1]

SVG animations can be created using the <animate> element. 
 
The example below creates a rectangle that will change its position in 3 seconds and will then repeat the animation twice: [code format="html" codeId="55"]<svg width="1000" height="250">
<rect width="150" height="150" fill="orange">
[b]  <animate[/b] attributeName="x" from="0" [b]to[/b]="300"
[b]    dur[/b]="3s" [b]fill[/b]="freeze" [b]repeatCount[/b]="2"/> 
</rect>
</svg>[/code]
[b]attributeName[/b]: Specifies which attribute will be affected by the animation
[b]from[/b]: Specifies the starting value of the attribute
[b]to[/b]: Specifies the ending value of the attribute
[b]dur[/b]: Specifies how long the animation runs (duration)
[b]fill[/b]: Specifies whether or not the attribute's value should return to its initial value when the animation is finished (Values: "remove" resets the value; "freeze" keeps the “to value”)
[b]repeatCount[/b]: Specifies the repeat count of the animation

In the example above, the rectangle changes its x attribute from 0 to 300 in 3 seconds.
[note]To repeat the animation indefinitely, use the value "[b]indefinite[/b]" for the repeatCount attribute.[/note]

quizzes.question:
Which shape is indicated by the following path?
<path d="M0 0  L0 100
    L100 100  L100 0  Z" />
quizzes.textContent:
[h1]Paths[/h1]

The <path> element is used to define a path.

[b][/b]The following commands are available for path data:
[b]M[/b]: moveto
[b]L[/b]: lineto
[b]H[/b]: horizontal lineto
[b]V: [/b]vertical lineto
[b]C[/b]: curveto
[b]S[/b]: smooth curveto
[b]Q[/b]: quadratic Bézier curve
[b]T[/b]: smooth quadratic Bézier curveto
[b]A: [/b]elliptical Arc
[b]Z[/b]: closepath

Define a path using the [b]d[/b] attribute: [code format="html" codeId="56"]<svg width="500" height="500">
<[b]path[/b] d="M 0 0 L200 200 L200 0 Z" style="stroke:#000;  fill:none;" />
</svg>[/code]
M places our "virtual pen" down at the position 0, 0. It then moves 200px down and to the right, then moves up to the position 200, 0. The Z command closes the shape, which results in a hypotenuse: [img id="2555" width="100%"]
[note]All of the above commands can also be expressed with lower case letters. When capital letters are used, it indicates absolute position; lower case indicates relative position.[/note]
